repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia, Mali, Morocco, South Africa,
            Tanzania, Tunisia - First Africa Stockpile Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Africa Stockpile
            Program Project for Ethiopia, Mali, Morocco, South Africa,
            Tanzania, and Tunisia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to global environment
            outcome was not applicable; Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            implementing agency and the World Bank team need to be
            staffed with technical expertise which is crucial for sound
            project preparation and implementation of projects
            associated with pesticide disposal. The project's
            effectiveness and development impact can significantly
            benefit from correct application of safeguard requirements.
            Sufficient time needs to be allocated for the preparation of
            required safeguard instruments. For multi-stakeholder
            projects, concise time and budget bound terms of reference
            for all partners need to be agreed on prior project effectiveness.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Africa Stockpiles Program Project
            : abbreviated resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The African Program for the stocks of
            obsolete pesticides (ASP) is an international initiative
            that was born of an awareness of the dangers of these
            products on the environment and human health. Tunisia was
            chosen among the seven (7) first African countries to
            benefit from assistance under this program in its first
            phase (2005-2009) in terms of promoting prevention and
            elimination. The fundamental objectives of the project
            ASP-Tunisia are: 1) Clean Tunisia stocks of obsolete
            pesticides without harming the environment and human health;
            2) Contribute to the prevention of recurrence of unwanted
            stock by the introduction of preventive measures; 3)
            Contribute to the protection of human health and
            environmental exposure to pesticides; and 4) Ensuring
            capacity building of Tunisian institutions on all important
            matters concerning chemicals in general and pesticides in
            particular. The project may cause many negative impacts
            including: a) The possible evacuation of affected
            populations; b) The emanation of odors and toxic fumes; c)
            The emission of dust; d) The accidental release and
            contamination of deposit (floor, walls, materials and
            equipment used); e) Contamination of soil, vegetation, air
            and water resources in case of large leaks; f) The risk of
            explosion, fire, burns and poisoning, and; g) Nuisance to
            local residents (smoke, odors, dust).

0.cdata!: Tunisie - Africa Stockpiles Programme

repnme.cdata!:
Africa - Africa Stockpiles Program Project
            : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment, removal, and disposal of
            obsolete pesticides, and the remediation of storage sites in
            the seven countries in Africa, within the framework of the
            Africa Stockpiles Program Project, will have considerable,
            positive environmental and social impacts. However, inherent
            in the project process, are unique environmental and social
            risks, identified in the Environmental Management Plan
            (EMP), which form the basis for the following mitigation
            measures. All participating countries are signatories of the
            Stockholm, Basel and Rotterdam Conventions, and each country
            program is based on multi-sectoral national steering
            committees, in close liaison with the technical support
            unit. The highest standards of vessel safety, and security
            will be ensured to minimize catastrophic accidents, i.e.,
            breakup of container vessels carrying hazardous materials.
            Handling of obsolete pesticides inventories shall be
            conducted by trained staff in accordance with standard
            environmental practices, who should in turn, be protected
            from human health hazards with appropriate gear and
            equipment. Pesticide removal and clean-up shall be in
            compliance with standard planning, and procedures. Each
            country's institutional and legal framework should
            establish and enforce legislation and standards to support
            implementation of the project, through effective regulatory
            management processes. In addition, risk assessment shall be
            conducted in a defined and consistent manner, a process by
            which priorities will be assigned for the clean-up of sites
            at the second stage. Monitoring criteria will be in place to
            ensure compliance with this EMP, by measuring effectiveness
            of mitigation under the second stage, taking into
            consideration specific country environmental elements (i.e.,
            economic value of land, agricultural production, water
            supplies, cultural heritage sites, biodiversity, among others).

display_title.display_title:
The assessment, removal, and
            disposal of obsolete pesticides, and the remediation of
            storage sites in the seven countries in Africa, within the
            framework of the Africa Stockpiles Program Project, will
            have considerable, positive environmental and social
            impacts. However, inherent in the project process, are
            unique environmental and social risks, identified in the
            Environmental Management Plan (EMP), which form the basis
            for the following mitigation measures. All participating
            countries are signatories of the Stockholm, Basel and
            Rotterdam Conventions, and each country program is based on
            multi-sectoral national steering committees, in close
            liaison with the technical support unit. The highest
            standards of vessel safety, and security will be ensured to
            minimize catastrophic accidents, i.e., breakup of container
            vessels carrying hazardous materials. Handling of obsolete
            pesticides inventories shall be conducted by trained staff
            in accordance with standard environmental practices, who
            should in turn, be protected from human health hazards with
            appropriate gear and equipment. Pesticide removal and
            clean-up shall be in compliance with standard planning, and
            procedures. Each country's institutional and legal
            framework should establish and enforce legislation and
            standards to support implementation of the project, through
            effective regulatory management processes. In addition, risk
            assessment shall be conducted in a defined and consistent
            manner, a process by which priorities will be assigned for
            the clean-up of sites at the second stage. Monitoring
            criteria will be in place to ensure compliance with this
            EMP, by measuring effectiveness of mitigation under the
            second stage, taking into consideration specific country
            environmental elements (i.e., economic value of land,
            agricultural production, water supplies, cultural heritage
            sites, biodiversity, among others). (Vol. 5) : Résumé analytique
